DIV1.P: Containing FIVE HUNDRED CUTS, of the most useful Plants, which are now used in the Practice of PHYSICK.
Engraved on folio Copper Plates. after Dramings, taken from the LIFE.
To which is added a short Description of Plants; and their common Uses in PHYSICK.

LIST.ITEM: 1. The Stalks grow about two Foot high, the Leaves are a grass Green. & ye Flowers yellow.
2. It grows in Woods & Hedges, flowring great part of the Summer.

3 The Roots are accounted cephalic and alexipharmic, cordial & chearing to ye Spirits, when infused in Wine. They are good for Pains arising from Cold or Wind in the Bowels, and are useful for all Kinds of Fluxes.
4. Greek, Latin. Caryphyllata vulgaris. Spanish. Italian. Garofanata. French. Benoiste. German. Benedictenwurt Dutch. Nagelkruyd.
1. The Stalks grow a Foot and an half high, the Leaves are a dark grass Green an the Face. and a willow Green on the Back.
2. It grows in moist Meadows. particularly Battersea, and flowers in May.
3. The Roots are eteem'd drying and binding, and useful in all Fluxes and Haemorrhagies, the Incontinence of Urine and making of bloody Water; and are serviceable in pestilential Fevers.
4. Greek. Latin. Bistorta radice mirus intorta. Spanish. Italian Bistorta. French. La Bistorte. German. Ratterwurt Dutch. Naterwortel.
1. The Stalks grow about two Foot high, the Leaves are a yellow grass Green. and the Flowers a dull yellow.
2. It is a native of Spain and Italy. and flowers here in May.
3. The Roots are accounted opening and attenuating. good to cleanse the Stomach and Lungs of tough Phlegm. promote the Menses, the Lochia, and the Birth
4 Greek. Latin. Aristolschia clematitis recta. Spanish. Astronomia Italian. Aristolochia. French. Aristoloche. German. Osterluen. Dutch. Lange en dunne Holwortel.
1 The Stalks of this grow less than the former. the Leaves are like the other. and the Flowers a deep Purple.
2 It grows in the same Countries. and flowers here in Man.

3 The Root is esteem'd good to purge chole and phlegma Humors. provoke the Catamenia. force away the Bh and After Birth. and ease the after Pains Outwardly is good to draw and Splinters and broken Bones. and Heal soul eating Ulcers
4 Greek. Latin. Aristolochia. rotund lore ax purpuns mro Spanish. Astronomia Italian. Aristolochia. French. Aristoloche German, Stolwurt Dutch. Ronde. Holwortel.

Aristolochia rotunda
1. The Stalks grow about two Foot high, the Leaves are a yellow grass Green, and the Flowers a dull Yellow.
2. It grows is Spain, Italy & ye Southern Parts of France. flowring here in May.

3. The Roots are accounted opening and attenuating. good to cleanse ye Lungs from tough Phlegm, promote the Menses and the Birth. & expel the Afterbirth. — Outwardly they are used to dry & cleanse foul Ulcers. The Root is one of the Ingredients in the Theriaca Andromachi.
4. Greek. . Latin. Aritolochia longa vera. Spanish. Astronomia. Italian, Aristologia longa. French. Aristologie. German. Lang Holwurts. Dutch. Lange Holwortel.
1. The Stalks grow near two Foot high, the Leaves are a dull blue Green. and the Flowers blue.
2. It grows in gravelly Grounds, flowring in May & Iune.

3. It is esteem'd warming & drying. good to comfort a cold windy Stomach, strengthen the Reins. help ye Fluor albus. and invigorate a cold relax'd Womb. The Seed of this Plant are remarkable to cleanse the Eyes from Redness. Inflammations or Specks.
4. Greek, . Latin, Occulus Christi. Spanish. Italian, Horminio salvatico. French. German, Bilde Salben. Dutch,
1. The Stalks grow about two Foot high, the Leaves are a light grass Green, and the Flowers yellow.
2. It grows in Ditches and watery Places, flowring in May.
3. This Plant is of a hot caustic Nature, and Histers with more violence than Cantharides. — The Root dryed & powdered provokes sneesing. when snuffed up the Nose, and helps to cleanse the Head
4. Greek, . Latin, Ranunculus Apii folio laevis. Spanish, Yerva belida. Italian. Ranoncolo. French, Grenoilette. German, Wasser Hanenfuss. Dutch.
1 The Stalks grow about two Foot high, the Leaves are a grass Green, and the Flowers white.
2 It grows in Ditches and Rills if Water, flowring in Inue.
3. The Leaves are said to consist of fine volatile Parts. being warming and opening good in all scorbutic Cases, as also the stone. Gravel & Jaundice. It is much eat as a Sallad in the Spring
4 Greek, . Latin, Nasturtium aquaticum supintn Spanish. Rabacas. Italian. Sto falso French. Berle. German, Welsomen. Dutch. Waterkersse.

Nasturtium aquaticum
1. The Stalks grow to be three or four Foot high, the Leaves are a grass Green, and the Flowers Yellow.
2. It grows in Ditches and watery Places flowring in May & Iune.
3. The Roots are accounted restringent drying and binding. good in all kinds of Fluxes. Some commend them as good to strengthen the Brain and Nerves.
4. Greek, Latin, Pseudo Acorus & Gladiolus luteus. Spanish, Italian, Giglio giallo. French, Flambe de Rivieres. German, Geel Schwertel. Dutch, Geele Lisch.
1. The Stalk grows about three Foot high the Leaves are a deep grass Green and the Flowers whitish.
2. It is planted in Gardens and flowers in May.

3. The Root purges less than that of the true Rhubarb; but is accounted more restringent and good in Fluxes Spitting of Blood, making of Bloody Water and Weakness of the Stomach. It is one of the Ingredients in the Theriaca Andromachi.
4. Greek, Latin, Lapathum praestantissimum, Rhabar∣barum officinatum dictum. Spanish. Italian, French, German, Dutch
1. The stalk grows about a Foot high, the Leaves are a light grass Green and the Flowers a whitish Green.
2. It grows upon old Stone Walls and Buildings, flowring in May.

3. The Leaves are esteemd cooling & moistning good in Diseases of the Liver prowking Urine & taking off the sharpness of it. - Outwardly applied, the Juice helps the Shingles, S'Anthony's fire, the Pain and Inflammation of the Piles; & eases Kibes & Chilblains. It is an Ingredient in the Unguentum Populeon. The Herb Folks too frequently impose the Frog-bit and the Marsh Penny wort, neither of which are used in the Shops, upon their unwary Customers instead of this Plant.
4. Greek, Latin Umlilicus Veneris. Spanish, Scudettes. Italian, Bellico di Venere. French, Escudes, German Nabel Craut Dutch Navelkruyd.
1. This Plant rarely comes to any considerable Height here, the Leaves are a blue Green & the Flowers white.
2 It grows in the southern Parts of France and Italy but produces its Gum in the more Eastern Countries

3 The Gum Dragon of the Shops comes from the Root of this Plant, being of a glutinous Nature good to correct the Acrimony & Sharpness of Humours easing Coughs Hoarsness and Caturrhous Deflexions Outwardly it is used in Callyriums for hot inflam'd Eyes
4 Greek . Latin, Tragacantha Spanish Mquitira. Italian, Traga∣cantha French, Barbe Renard German Dragant Dutch Gum Dragon Boom.

Tragacantha
1. The Stalks grow about two Foot high, the Leaves are a deep Green, and the Flwers a blue Purple.
2. It is a native of Italy, and flowers here in Iune.

3. The Seed powdered is commended by Slvius de la Boe, from gr XII to a Scruple in a Dose, to purge upwards & downwards, and cause a grat Flux of Spittle, being serviceable against the Lues Venerea. Some use it in Gargarisms for the Tooth-Ach, and the Vulgar use it to kill Lice; from which it has the Name of Lousewort.
4. Greek, . Latin, Staphis agria. Spanish, Fabaraz. Italian, Stafusaria. French, Herbe aux Poux. German. Bissmunk. Dutch. Luyskruyd.
1. The Stalks grow about two Foot high, the Leaves are a light grass Green, and the Flowers yellow.
2. It grows upon old Walls, as on the Walls of the City of London, and flowers several Months in the Summer.
3. The Whole Plant is accounted hot dry and diuretic, & a provocative to Venery Matthiolus prefers this before ye Garden Rocket. See Place 242.
4 Greek . Latin, Eruca sylvestris major lutea caule aspero. Spanish, Arugua. Italian, Rucola salvatica. French Roquette sauvage. German, Wild Weiss Scuff. Dutch. Bilde Rakette.
1 This grows to be a large Tree in the West Indies, the Leaves are a grass Green and the Flowers yellow.
2 It is a native of Virginia, and flowers here in April.

3 The Root and Bark are accounted heating and drying, good for the Scurvy. Gout and Dropsy, and are commonly an Ingredient in Dyet Drinks for the Lues Venerea. The Tea made of the shavings is much drank for catarrhous Defluxions and shortness of Breach. The Offici∣nal Preparations are the Electuarium e Sassafras & the Chimical Oil.
4 Greek, Latin. Arbor ex Florida Ficulneo folio. Spanish, Italian. French. German. Dutch.
1 The stalks grow about two Foot high, the Leaves are a blue Green, and the Flowers white.
2 It grows in Meddows & Corn fields flowring in Iune.
3 The Root is esteem'd cordial cephalic alexipharmic and a Prowca∣tire to Venery.
4 Greek Latin. Luchms sylvestris Spanish. Italian. Lichmde coronarta French. German. Marenron Dutch. Witte Been

Behen album
1. The Stalk grows near three Foot high, the Leaves are a shining grass Green, and the Flowers green on the outside and Purple within.
2. It is planted here in Gardens, and flowers in Iune.

3. This Plant is accounted alexipharmic. good in malignant contagious Dis∣tempers, and pestilential Fevers; and is very useful to drive any thing out from the Heart, for which it is griven in the small Pox & Measles.
4 Greek. . latin. Dracunculus polyphyllus. Spanish. Taragontia. Italian. Dragontea. French. Petite Serpentaire. German. Gross Schlang encruut. Dutch. Dragon.
1 It grows near two Foot-high, the Leaves are a willow Green, and the Flowers a fine Blue.
2 It gorws amonast the sorn, and flowers in Iune & Iuly.

3 The Leaves and Flowers are said to have the same Vertues as those of the great Blue-Bottle. see Plate . Some commend the Distill'd Water of the Flowers for sore. inflam'd and bloodshot Eyes. The Infusion and Powder of the Flowers are given as a Remedy against the Jaundice.
4 Greek . Latin. Cyanus segetum. Spanish. Italian. For menore French. German. Kornblum. Dutch. Koorn-bloem.
1. The Stalks grows about three Foot high. the Leaves are a bright grass Green, and the Flowers a pale Red.
2 It grows in Woods. flowring in May and Iune.

3 This Plant is much used for Diseases of the Head and all nervire Affections. Columna commends the Powder of the Root as good for the Epilepsy. Some Phy∣sicians prescribe Tea made from the Roots as a good Medicine for ye above mention'd Distemper, after proper Evacuations.
4 Greek . Latin, Valertana sylvestris major foliis angustioribus. Spanish, Yerva beneditta. Italian. Valeriana. minore French. Valere desprez. German. Gemein Baldrian Dutch. Weild Valeriana.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 272. Golden Starnort Aster Atticus luteus.

LIST.ITEM: 1 It grows about a Foot and an half high, the Leaves are a dull grass Green and the Flowers yellow.
2 It is a Native of Italy and Spain, and is planted here in Gardens slowring in Iune.

3 The Ancients held this Plant in great Esteem for Buboes & swellings in the Grein. the Leaves being applyed as a Cataplasm. and affirm that holding them only in the Hand will dpate these Swellings. which is haly to be credited
4 Greed . Latin Aster luteus follis ad florem Spanish. Italian Asteratico French, Pe Mugue German Stern Krunt Dutch.

2. It grows in Ditches and watery Places, flowring in Iune.
3. Gerard gives this Plant great Commendations for a good vulnerary, to cure all green Wounds, beaten to a cataplasm, with Hogs Lard-Some commend it for all kinds of Haemorrhagies.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 274. Female Pimpernell. Anagallis terrestris foemina.

LIST.ITEM: 1 The stalks grow near a Foot high, the Leaves are a blue Green and the Flowers blue.
2 It grows in some Corn Fields, and flowers in Iune.
3 This plant has much the same Vertues with the other. see Plate 43. being accounted a good vulnerary and useful in Consumptions and malignant Distempers &c.
4 Greek. . Latin, Anagallis coeruleo flore, Spanish Murugues. Italian Anagallo foemi. French, Mouron. German, Gauchbeyl weible Dutch.
1 The stalks, grow about four Foot high, the Leaves are a bright grass Green, and the Flowers yellow.
2. It is od here in Gardens, and flowers in Iune.
3 The Roots. Leaves and Seed are esteemd heating and drying good to warm the Stomach, expel Wind. provoke Urine and the Menses; and are useful in Agues and Pestilential Distempers.
4 Greek . Latin. Ligusticum vulgare. Spanish, Italian, Levistico French, Achelarge. German, Liebstoctel. Dutch. Lavas.

2 It grows in moist Meadows flowring in Iune and Iuly.

3 This Plant is used in Sallads to correct the Coldness of other Herbs. The Roots held in the Mouth, are said to ease the Th Ach. by evacuating the Rheum. like Pellitory of Spain - The Powder of the Herb snuffd up the Nose provokes Sneezing and cleanses the Head of Humours.

2. It is planced in Gardens flowring in March and April.
3. The Berries are esteem'd cooling and restringent good to create an Appetite and quench Thirst.
4. Greek, Latin, Uva crispa. Spanish. Italian. Uva spina. French, Groiselier. German, Creukbeer. Dutch. Kruys Besien.

2. It grows in watary Places by River. Sides. flowring in Iune & Iuly.
3. The Ancients commend it for a great restringent, good for all kinds of Fluxes, as also to consolidats ye Lips of fresh Wounds, and heal them.
4. Greek, . Latin, Lysimachia luta major. Spanish, Italian, Lisimachia. French. German, Gelb-Beiderich. Dutch,
1. The Stalks grow about a Foot high, the Leaves are a bright grass Green and the Flowers white.
2. It is a Native of the Austrian and Stirian Mountains and flowers here in Iune and Iuly.

3. The Roots are esteem'd cordial, Sudorific & Maxipharmic of great Service in malignant Fevers, and all nervine Affections & Disorders of the Head; they are used to ease ye Pains of the Stomach & Collick.

3 It is accounted good for Obstructions of the Liver Ereast & Womb; helping the Jau ness of Breath & stoppage of the Menses. It comforts the Head & Nerves and the distilled Oil helps ye Tooth-Ach. being put upon Lant into the awing Tooth.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 283. Would or dyers Weed. Luteola.

LIST.ITEM: 1. It grows about a yard high, the Leaves are a pale Green, and the Flowers yellow.
2. It grows on Dry Banks and flowers in Iune.

Lotus Urbana
1. It grows to be five or six Foot high; the Leaves are a dark grass Green, & the Flowers in very light Green.
2. It is planted in Gardens, and flowers in April.
3. Currans are accounted cooling and grateful to the Stomach, good to quench Thirst, & are somewhat restringent. A Jelly made of the Juice and Sugar is cooling and good in Fevers.
4. Greek, Latin, Ribesia. & Grossularia non Spinosa. Spanish. Italian. Ribes. French, Ribettes. German. S. Johanns Treublein. Dutch, Roode Alheesien.
1 The stalks grow about eight Inches high, the Leaves are a deep grass Green. & the Flowers a light Green with yellow Stamina.
2 It grows in moist shady Woods, particularly in a Wood, by the Bog at Chiselhurst in Kent; at the Entrance of it next the Town. It flowers in April and May. and the Berry is ripe in July.

3 Fuchsius accounted this Plant of a poisonous Nature, but later Writers esteem it a counter Poison, and alexipharmia good in malig∣nant and pestilential Fevers. Parkinson says the Roots boil'd in Wine help the collic, and the Leaves applyed outwardly, repress Tumours and Inflammations especially in the Scrotum and Testicles.
4 Greek, Latin, Solanum quadrifolium bacciferum. Spanish, Italian. Herba Paris. French, raisin de Renard. German, Sterneraut. Dutch.
1. The Stalk grows near a Foot high, the Leaves are a reddish Green, and the Flowers yellow.
2 It is sown in Gardens. and flowers in July.
3 The Leaves are esteem'd cooling. good or the Scurvy. the Heat of the Bile. Heat of Urine. Serangury and a Gonorrhea. The Seed is cooling and restringent. good to kill Worms.

1. It grows to be four or five Foot high, the Leaves are a deep Greena bove & hoary underneath. & the Flower a pale Red.
2 It grows wild in some Parts of Wales, and the North of England; and flowers in May, the Fruit being ripe in June and July.
3. The Fruit is accounted cordial, good to strengthen the Stomach, stay Vomiting. and prevent Miscarriage. The Officinal Preparation is the Syrupus de Jdoeo.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 305. The Samson Tree. Prunus Damascena.

LIST.ITEM: 1. This Tree Sedome grows to any great Heigth here; the Leaves are: as deep Green, & the Flowers white with yellow Stumina.
2. It grows wild in seweral Parts of England & flowers in April.
3. The Fruit is used at Table more than in the Apothecary's Shops; & are given to Persons in Fevers to cool them.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 306. French Sorrel. Acetosa Romana rotundifolia.

LIST.ITEM: 1. The Stalks grow about a Foot high, the Leaves are a bluish Green, and the Flowers yellow.
2. It is sown in Gardens. and flowers in June.
3. The Leaves are cooling & cordial. resisting Putrefaction. and are good in Fevers. and the Scurvy; for which last they are commend∣ed to be eat in Sallads.

3. It is esteem'd good to allay Thirst and repress Bile in Fevers. having much the same Vertues as the common Sorrel. but in a less Degree.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 321. The Roman Nettle. Urtica Romana.

LIST.ITEM: 1. It grows about a Foot & an half high; the Leaves are a deep grass Green, and the Flowers a dull yellow.
2. It grows frequently about yarmouth and Romney Marsh, and flowers in July.
3. This is much of the Nature of the common Nettle, see Plate 12. but the Seed is accounted a beater Pectoral, and of grater Service against Coughs and Affections of the Lungs.
4. Greek, . Latin, Urtica urens, pilulas ferens. Spanish, Ortiga. Italian, Ortica, French, Ortie. German, Romisch Nessel. Dutch, Roomse Nettelen.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 322. The Female Hemp. Cannabis foemina.

LIST.ITEM: 1. The Stalks grow about five Foot high, the Leaves are a deep Green above and a light Green underneath.
2. It is planted in Fields and Gaardens yearly, & produces its Seed in August; for this Species of Hemp never bears any visible Flower.
3. The Seed being boild in Milk, till it cracks, is accounted good for old Coughs, and a Specific to cure the Jaundice.
4. Greek, . Latin, Cannabis. Spanish, Canamho. Italian, Canapo. French, Chanure. German, Hanff. Dutch, Henniss.
1. The Leaves of this Fearn grow about two Foot high, and are of a yellow Green Colour; and the Seed brown.
2. It grows in Hedges & shady Lanes, bearing Seed in August.
3. The Root is said to be hurtful to the Female Sex, and to cause Miscarriage; but is accounted good for Obstructions of the Liver and Spleen.

1. The Leaves grow about three Foot high, and are of a pale Green Colour, and the Seed brown when ripe.
2. It grows in marshy and boggy Places, particularly in a Bog at the Backside of Woolwich, near the Warren. & the Seed is ripe in August.
3. The Roots are esteem'd good for Rickets in Children, as also for Ruptures Wounds & Bruises: and for Obstructions of ye Lieer & Spleen

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 333. The Succotrine Aloe. Aloe Succotrina.

LIST.ITEM: 1. The Stalks grow about three Foot high, the Leaves are a blue Green, and the Flowers a light Red.
2. It is a Native of the East and flowers here in December.

3. The best Aloes of this Species comes over in skins from the Island Succotora. - Aloes is a great Ingredient in most of the officinal Pills, being accounted a good Stomatic, and useful to carry off tough & slimy Humors from the Bowels. Outwardly it is used for fresh Wounds, a little of the fine Powder being put in them.
4. Greek, . Latin, Aloe succotrina, angustifolia spinosa, flore purpureo. Spanish, Azibar Cicotrino. Italian, Aloe. French, Aloes. German, Aloen. Dutch, Aloe.
1. This fungous Excressens is wrinkled. & turn'd up like an Ear and is whitish on the outside & black within, with several little Veins.
2. It grows on the Trunk of the Elder.
3. Iews Ears are esteem'd good for the swelling and Inflammation of the Tonsils, sore Throats and Luinseys.
4. Greek, Latin, Atiriculae Judeorum Spanish. Orejas de las Judias. Italian. Orecchia di Judeas. French, Oreilles des Juifs. German, Dutch.
1. This Moss has wrinkled tough Leaves, greenish above, & Ash colourd underneath.
2. It grows upon the Trunk of the Oak.

3. It is accounted good to stop inward Bleeding & the great Flux of the Menses. The common People use it for all Disorders of the Lungs & Breast boiling it in Pectoral Drinks, & making Syrups of it. The German Ephemerides Anno Obs 290 commend it as an extraordinary Remedy for ye yellow Jaundice.
4. Greek, Latin. Lichen arborum Spanish. Pulmonaris de Arbol Italian Pubnonarta French. Pulmonaire d Arbre German. Lungencraut Dutch. Lunge Kruyd.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 336 Ash colourd Liverwort. Lichen cinereus.

LIST.ITEM: 1 This Lichen is ash colour above and whitish underneath.
2 It grows on Barren Plo and heaths and is in perfection in October.

3 This Plant is that which the great Doctor Mead has found out to be a Specific for the Cure of the Bite of a mad Dog and is to be taken in the manner following word Let the Patient be blooded at the arm nine or ten ounces. Take of the Hers Latin Iachen Terrestris in English Ash colourd these well together and the powder into four doses one which must be taken every morning for four mornings a pint of warm. After these four doses are the must into the cold Bath or a cold spring or river every morning for a month he must be dipt all ever but not stay with his head above water longer than half a minute ye the water be very cold After this he must go in times a weed for a fortnight longer.
4 Greek . Latin Ltien Spanish Higadela Italtan hene French Epatiqe German Stein Zeber rant Dutch.

1. This is a low Shrubby Tree or Bush with Leaves like those of the Laurel and Flowers like the Jasmine.
2. It grows in Arabia Felix; and flowers here in April and May.

3. The Coffee that is commonly drank, is made of the Berries of this Tree roasted; and is accounted good for those who are of a cold flgmatic Cons∣titution. But for Persons of a thin hot and dry Temperament, the drinking it too much may bring on them Nervous Distempers.
4. Greek, . Latin, Euonimo similis Aegyptiaca fructu Baccis Lauri simili. Spanish, Cafá. Italian, Caffé French, Caffe. German, Dutch.
1. The Trunk of this Tree grows about the Bigness of a Man's Waist, the Leaves resemble those of ye Bay, in shape size and Colour the Flower is red, and the Seed a reddish Brown.
2. It grows in the Molucca Islands, in the East Indies; and this Specimen was taken from a Branch of the Tree at Sr Hans Sloan's.

3. Cloves are esteem'd heating, drying, cordial cephalic and Stomatic; being good to stop Vomiting, strengthen a weak Stomach expel Wind prevent Fainting and malignant Distempers. The Distill'd oyl is said to cure the Tooth-Ach, a Bit of Lint being dipp'd in it, and put into the Hollow Tooth.
4. Greek . Latin Caryophyllus. Spanish. Clavos. Italian. Garofoli. French. Girofle German. Negelen Dutch Negelein.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 339. The true Euphorbium. Euphorbium. verum Antiquorum

LIST.ITEM: 1 This Specimen was taken from a Plant in the Green house in Chelsea Garden, about three Foot high, & much branch'd answering the Description of that in Miller's Botanicum Officinale the Stalks being triangular of a light grass Green and very Prickly: the Flower is whitish, with a little tincture of Red on the Back of the Leaves.
2. It grows in Barbary and the East Indies.

3. This Plant is full of a caustic Milk which when dryed is the Euphorbium of the Shops; being a violent Sternlatory and is sometimes used in Apoplexies and Lethargies. Outwardly it is used to clean foul and rotten Bones and is put in to Drawing Plaisters.
4. Greek. . Latin Euphorbium, Spanish. Euphorbio Imlion, Euforbio. French, Euphorbe German. Dutch.

1 This Specimen was taken from a Plant about three Foot high in ye Green house which is said to be an other Species of the Euphorbium. & is shewn on Lecture Days with the former. It differs from the other both in Shape and Colour this growing very much like a torch Thistle having young Buds on the Sides like those of ye Indian Fig, and of a blue Green Colour.
2 It grows in the same Countries as the other but it has not flowred in England nor has any Herbal taken Notice of the Flower and Fruit.
3 The same Qualities are given to this as the Former.
4 Greek . Latin. Euphorbium Spanish, Euphorbio Italian French. Euphorbe German. Dutch.

2. It grows upon the Rocks at the Bottom of the Tyrrhenian Sea, and on the Coasts of Spain and France; this Specimen was taken from a Branch in Mr. Nicholls's curious Collection.

3. Coral is esteem'd cordial drying & restringent good to sweeten the Blood and free the Stomach from Acid Sour Juices; it stops all kinds of Fluxes and Hoemorrhagies; & wherever an Alkali is necessary, this will do as much as any. DIV2.HEAD: Plate 342. Ture White Coral. Corallium verum album. White Coral of the Shops. Corallium Officinarum.

LIST.ITEM: 1 The true white Coral is never to be met with in the Shops, & rarely in any Cabinet; this Specimen was taken from a Branch in Sr. Hans Sloan's unparalleld Collection, & is Numbered 178. in his Cabinet being one of the greatest Rarities there; the other Coral is the Corallium Officinarum of Lobel and C. Bauhin, but Tournefort makes it a Madrepora; this Specimen was taken from Mr. Nicholls's curious Collection: and was the Coral of ye Shops in Lobels time.
2. The true white Coral grows in the Spanish West India Seas & the other grows in the Mediterranean Seas.
3. White Coral is cooling and binding good for the Heart-burn or any Dis∣orders that proceed from sharp Acid Juices in the Stomach or Blood.
4 Greek, . Latin, Corallium uerum album & Corallium Offici∣narum Spanish, Coral blanco Italian Corallo bianco French, Corail blanche German, Gorall Dutch, Koraal.

2. Both these Sorts of Coral grow on the Rocks of the Western Ocean & the Coast of France.
3 These Corale have the same Qualities as the former, and such Corals as are whitest and firmest in their texture are esteem'd the Best.
4 Greek . Latin Corallium album Spanish Coral blanco Italian Corallo bianco French. Corail blanche German. Gorall Dutch. Koraal.

Gum Araback comes from this Tree, which is very serviceable in Coughs & the Heat of Urine.

2. It grows in Spain. Italy and Portugal, and flowers all the Year.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 350 Pockwood or Lignum Vitae. Guajacum.

2. The first Species grows in Jamaica, and the last in Brasile.
3 The Bark & Wood are good for the Dropsy, Gout. King's Evil and the Lues Venerea. The Gum is useful in Scorbutick Cases or any Breaking out of the Skin.

3 This Tea is accounted good to purify the Blood, promote Digestion, strengthen the Head, provoke Urine and prevent the Stone and Gout. But it must be drank moderately

1. This Tree grows as big as a Pear-Tree, the Leaves are a grass Green and the Flowers yellowish; which are succeeded by Fruit as big as a Peach. whose outward covering is soft and juicy like that of a Walnut, under which lies the Mace, firmly sticking to the hard Woody Shell; that contains the Nutmeg of the Shops. This Specimen is taken from Sr. Hans Sloan's Collection, but the unripe and ripe Fruit are taken from some that Mr. Rand had preserved on the Island, and are as large as the Life.
2. It grows chiefly in Banda, an Island in the East Indies.

3. Nutmegs are heating. drying and carminative; good to strengthen the Stomach and Bowels, stop Vomiting, help Digestion, comfort the Head & Nerves, prevent Swooning, & Miscarriage. The Mace has much the same Qualities but more penetrating: & is also accounted good for the Sight & to strengthen the Memory.
4 Greek, . Latin. Muristicae. Spanish Nuez de Especte Italian, Noci Moschade. French. Nois Muscades. German, Muscatennuss. Dutch,
1 This Tree grows large in its Native Climate. the Leaves are a willow Green. & the Flowers whitish. This Specimen is token from Sr Hans Sloan's Collection.
2 It grows in the Island of Celkon in the East Indies.

3. The Cinamon of the Shops is the Bark of this Tree, its outside being first pared off, and is accounted cordial and restringent good in Diarrheas & Fluxes; nd is an INgredient in all the Capital Medicines. Officinal Preparatinos are. the Aqua Cinamomo fortis et tenuts, the Distill'd Oil, the Syrupus de Cinamomo and the Pulins Diaemnamomi.
4. Greek. . Latin. Cinnamomum. Spanish, Canola. Italian, Canella. French, Canelle. German. Zimmet coezlen. Dutch,

2 I grows on the hilly Parts of the Island of Jamaica. and flowers in. June, July and August.
3. The Fruit is accounted cordial and Stomatic. good to expell Wind. strengthen the Stomach, Bonels and Nerves, and help the Collic.
4 Greek, . Latin, Pimenta. Spanish. Pimienta de Jamaica Italian, Pevero French. Poivre de Jamaique German. Pfeffer. Dutch.

2. It is cltivated in Greece, Turky. Sicily and Malta: & flowers in June.
3. The Seed is accounted balsamic and. restringent, good for Coughs, shortness of Breath, soreness of Lungs. and Fluxes of all sorts.

3. The Dragon's Blood of the Shops comes from this Tree. and is esteem'd restrin∣gent, drying and binding; good for Diarrhaeas Dysenteries, spitting of Blood and all kinds of Haemorrhagies. It also fastens loose Teeth, and stops the Bleeding of the Gums & helps the Scurvy in them.

3. The Roots are accounted cordial. alexipharmic and sudorific good in all malignant contagious Fevers; it also helps the Collic and strengthens the Stomach.

1. This Tree does not grow very big in its Native Climates: The Leaves are light grass Green and the Flowers white.
2. It grows in the West Indies, and flowers in the Spring.

3. The Peel is esteem'd drying. warming. & alexipharmic, good to streng then the Stomach, and help malignant & pestilential Distempers. The Juice is cooling and sudorific, good to resist Putrefaction, and useful in all kinds of Fevers. The Seed is said to partake of the same Vertues, in a lower Degree, and is also good to destroy Worms. Officinal Preparations are, Aqua Corticum Citri. Syrupus è Succo, & è Corticibus Citrs.

2. It grows in Spain & Portugal & flowers for several Months in the Summer.

3 Lemons are cooling & grateful to the Stomach, and very useful in all sorts of Fevers; they are also good for the Stone & stoppage of Urine. — The Juice mixt with Salt of Wormwood is accounted an excellent Medicine to stop Vomiting & strengthen ye Stomach. The Officinal Preparation is. The Syrup of the Juice.

3. This is the maiden-Hair that ought to be used in making the Syrup, and every where else. where the true is prescribed; but the English Maiden-Hair generally supplys its Place. The true Maiden-Hair is opening & Attenuating. good for all Distempers of the Lungs and Breast. as Coughs, shortness of Breath, Hoarsness and the like. 1. The Stalks grow about a Span long, the Leaves are a grass Green, and the Seed brown.
2. It grows in Shady Lanes and on old Stone Buildings.
3. This is used instead of the cure Capillus veneris, and is accounted good for Coughs, Consumptions, the Stone. Gravel, and stoppage of Urine.
4. Greek, Latin, Polytrichum. Spanish. Italian, Capel venere, French, Politrie. German, Stein-brech. Dutch. Brouwen-hair.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 371. The true Amomum. Amomum verum.

LIST.ITEM: 1. This Specimen is taken from Mr Joseph Millar's the Apothecary.
2. It grows in Bunches of roundish triangular Capsulae, containing black cornerd rough Seed.
3. This Amomum is warming and comforting, and is good for the Collie. and cold Disorders of the Stomach and Bowels. It also promotes Urine and the Catamenia.
4. Greek Auouo. Latin, Amomum Racemosum. Spanish, Amomo. Italian. Amomo. French, Amome. German. Dutch.
1 The Stalks grow about two Foot high, the Leaves are a grass Green. and the Flowers white.
2 It grows in Hedges and Bank Ades. flowring in May.
3 The Leaves are good to provoke Urine and help à Dropsy, the Jucc must with Honey eases an old Cough Outwardly, the Leaves are very good for Gangrens

1. This Tree grows to be pretty big in its native Climates, the Leaves are a deep Green & the Flowers yellow. This Specimen is taken from Mr Joseph Millars Colleaon.
2. It gorws in Jamaica and Martinico; but the Best grow in the Caracces, in New Spain.
3. The Kernels of the Nuts is what we make the Chocolate of. which is now so much used for Food; being accounted nourishing, restorative, fawing & provocative.
4. Greek, Latin, Amigdalis similis Guatimelensis. Spanish, Cacao. Italian, Cacao. French, Cacao. German, Dutch, Cacouw.
1 It grows about two Foot high the Leaves are a pale Green & ye FLowers white.
2. It grows in Germany and Spain and flowers in July.

3. The Seed is one of the four greater hot Seeds; and is esteemed good to expell Wind out of the Stomach and Bowels, either taken at the Mouth or applyed as a Glyster. It is also used fot cold affections of the Lungs, Difficulty of Breath∣ing and Asthma. The Oil distilld from the Seed is often used in Carminative and Anodine Linaments. particularly for the Fleurisv and other pains in the Side. The Officinal Preparation is, the Chimical Oil distiled from the Seed.
4. Greek, . Latin, Anisum Herbartis. Spanish. Anis. Italian. Antso. French, Anis. German, Anyss, Dutch. Anys.
1 This Plant grows about four or five Inches high, the Leaves are a shining yellowish Brown, and the Flowers or Caps gold colour.
2 It grow on Heaths and Old Ant Hills flowring in october.
3. This is one of the five Capillary Plants, and is said to be good for Coughs and all Affections of the Lungs and Diseases of the Kidneys.
4. Greek, Latin. Polytrichum aureum majus. Spanish. Politree. Italian, Capel venere. French, Gurguet. German. Fraunen Haar. Dutch, Venus-Hair.

2 It is planted in Gardens and flowers in March and April

3 The Leaves are accounted pectoral and balsamue. good for Coughs. . spitting of Blood. and the like Disorders of the Lungs They are also put unto Wound-Drinks and traumatic Decections and good to head Wounds Ulcers and old Sores.

1. This gorws to be a pretty big Tree; the Leaves are a bright grass Green, and the Flowers yellow. The Thorns grow on the stronger Branches.
2. It grows in the Eastern Countries particularly in Aegypt.

3. The true Acacia of the Ancients is made from the Pods of this Tree, before they are ripe; and is accounted restringent, cooling and incrassiating. good against spitting of Blood and all kinds of Fluxes; but it is rarely to be met with in the Shops now a Days. Gum Arabick comes from this Tree, which is very serviceable in Coughs and the Heat of Urine.
4. Greek. . Latin, Acacia folits scorpioides leguminosae. Spanish. Italian, French, German, Dutch,

2 It is sown in Gardens and flowers in June.

3. This Plant is much eat as a Sallad; and is accounted cooling & mest∣ning. good to open obstructions of the Liver and Spleen, and help ye Jaun∣dic. provoke Urine, and cool a hot Stomach. The Seed is one of the Lesser cold Seeds.
4. Greek, . Latin, Scartola. Sertola & Jntybds sativa latifolia. Spanish, Escarola. Italian. Indiva. French. Scariole. German. Enden. Dutch, Endivie.

2. It is sown in Gardens, and flowers in July.
3 This Plant is more used in the Kitchen than the Sheps. and is esteemed nourishing and a provocative to Venery. Doctor Boerhave commends it for the Strangury & the obstruction of the Menses.
4. Greek, / Latin, Pastinaca sativa latiflia Spanish, Chirua Italian, Pastinaca. French, Panais. German, pastmach Dutch. pastmaken.

1. This grows to be a large Tree, the Leaves are a light grass Green, and the Flowers yellow.
2. It grows in the East and West Indies, and in Aegypt.

3. The Pulp. which is found in the Pod, is accounted a very gentle Purge, being good to carry off serous and bilous Humours, and ease the Gripes. It is also useful for the Stone, Heat of Urine, & a Gonorrhea. Officinal Preparations are, Cassta extracta cum et sine Folus Sinnae, & the Dia Cassia cum Manna.
4. Greek, Latin, Cassia fistula Alexandrina. Spanish, Cassia. Italian, Cassia. French, Casu laxative. German, Cassien. Dutch, Pyp-kassie.

2. It is sown here in Gardens & flowers in June & July; after it has stood some years
3. The Seed is esteem'd good to expell Wind, help the Collic, provoke Urine and the Catamenia; & is an Ingredient in the Theriaca Andromachi.

2. It is planted here in Gardens, and flowers in May.

3. The Roots and Leaves are said to be good to purge tough Phlegm and Choler from the Stomach and Bowels, and are very serviceable in stubborn tertian. or quartan Agues, the Dropsy, Gout and Jaundice. A Decoction of the Root powerfully provokes Urine & the Menses; and the dryed Leaves powdered, are used by some as Snuff to evacuate mucous Humours from the Head.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 385. The greater & lesser Cardamons & Grains of Paradyce. Cardamomum majus, minus et maximum; vel Grana Paradisi.

LIST.ITEM: 1. The greater Cardamons are long, somewhat triangular, Pods; full of corner'd, known here. They grow in the Island of Java in the East Indies. The Lesser Cardamoms are small triangular Capsulae containing several corner'd brown Grains of an hot, spicy, aromatic Taste, and a pleasant Smell. They grow in the East Indies. The Grains of Paradyce. or the largest Cardamoms are of a reddish brown Colour, and a hot biting Taste; but not so aromatic as the other Cardamons; these Grains grow in roundish Pods, in shape like an unripe Fig. They grow in Guinea; but the Tree is not known here. The Fruit and Seed of these Three Cardamoms I had from Mr. Joseph Millar, and the Specimen of the Tree of the Lesser Cardamoms is taken from the Malabar Garden Vobu Tab 5.

3. The Seed of all these Three is said to be good to comfort and strengthen the Stomach and Bowels, help Digestion, the Jaundice and the Collic, ease Distempers of the Head and Nerves, provoke Urine and the Menses.

4. Gree, . Latin, Cardamomum majus vulgare, Cardamomum minus vulgare, Malligatte, Spanish, Cardamomo, Grana de Paradiso. Italian, Cardamono. Cardamo. French, Cardamine, Maniguette, Grains de Paradis. German, Cardamom∣lein & Paradeiss-Gorner. Dutch, Kleine Kardamom, & Parady's-Koorn, & Paradys grein.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 386. The Ben. Nut or oily Acorn. Balanus Myrepsica.

LIST.ITEM: 1. This Tree grows about Thirty Foot high, the Leaves are a deep Green on the Face and light underneath: and the Flowers white.
2. It grows in Arabia. Aequpt, Syria & Barbary The Fruit of this I had from Mr. Joseph Millar, & the Tree from the Malabar Garden Vol. 6 Tab 19.
3. The Nuts are sai to purge and evacuate bile & Flegm upwards & down∣ward. - The Oil is goodto cure the Itch & Scabs, & to take away Freckles & Morphew
4. Greek, Latin, Nux Ben, & Glans unguentaria. Spanish, Ben. Italian, Ben. French, Ben. German. Dutch, Moringe.
1. This grows to be a large Tree, the Leaves are a grass Green & the Flowers whitish
2 It grows in the East Indies The Fruit of this I had from Mr Joseph Mallar, and the Tree from the Malabar Garden Vol 1 Tab. 9.

3 The Fruit is esteem'd good to strengthen the Stomach, help Fluxes, and spitting of Blood - Some recommend it as great Secret for the Cure of the Kings Evil, and to rectify decayed Juices, and restore a Morbid Habit of Body.
4. Greek, Latin, Faufed Avellana Indiana versicolor Spanish, Avellana de la India Intalian, Avellana de India. French. Aveline & Ind German. Dutch.

2 It grows in Pertugal & the East Indies and generally beart Fruit in March and September This Specimen I had from the Malabar Garden Fol 4 Tab. 41.

3 Gum Lacca is accounted opening & attenuating good to remove Contractions of the Liver & Spleen help the Dropsy & Jaundice provoke Urine and purtly the Eleed and to which used for making the finese Sealing War.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 389. The India Berry Tree. Natsjatam

LIST.ITEM: 1. This Tree grows pretty large in its Native Climate; the Leaves are a deep Green above and a dull Green underneath, the Flowers white with yellow Apices, & the Fruit black when ripe. This Specimen I had from the Mala∣bar Garden, Vol. 7. Tab. 1. & the separate Fruit from Mr. Joseph Millar.
2. It grows in Malabar in the East Indies.
3. The Fruit is said to be of a poisonous nature; & is used outwardly to kill Lice in Peoples Heads. Some Persons mix the Berries with their Bait to catch Fish.
4. Greek. Latin, Cocculus Indus & Cocculae officinarum. Spanish, Pavos de las Indias. Italian, Galuzza di Levante. French, Cogue du Levant. German, Doll-Gorner. Dutch, Kockles, & Water quaad.
1. The Stalks grow about a Foot high, the Leavesare a bluish Green, and the Flowers white above and purple underneath.
2. It grows in Spain, and flowers in July.

3. The Root is accounted good for the Tooth Ach, held between the Teeth it draws forth the cold watery Rheum; it is also good for the Palsy of the Tongue, for which it is put into Masticatories, and drawing Cataplasms and Plaisters; particularly the Emplastrum Cephallicum.
4. Greek, . Latin, Pyrethrum vulgare officinarum. Spanish, Pelitre. Italian, Piretro. French. Pyrethre German, Bertram. Dutch. Bertram-Kruyd.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 391. Malabar or Iava Cinamon. Cassia lignea.

LIST.ITEM: 1. This Tree grow about thirty Foot high, the Leaves are a light Green, the Flowers a greenish White with white. Stamina & yellow Apices; and the Fruit a deep Purple when ripe. This Specimen I had from the Mala∣bar Garden. Vol. 1. Tab. 57. & the Bark from Mr. Joseph Millar.
2. It grows in the East Indies, and flowers in January.
3. The Bark of this Tree has the same Virtues as that of the Cinamon; see Plate 345. but in a lower Degree; being sciptic and restringent & good in all kinds of Fluxes and Loosnesses.
4. Greek, . Latin, Canella Malavarica. Spanish, Canela de Malabar. Italian, Canella di Malabar. French, Canelle de Malabar. German, Genel. Dutch, Kaneel.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 392. The Gamboodge Tree. Coddam-pulli & Carcapuli

2 It grows in the East Indies and flowers in March.

3 The Gamboodge of the Shops comes from this Tree, and is a wary strong Cathartic, purging serous watery Humours, pretty Smartly, and when applyed by a Skilfull Hand, is of great Service in the Dropsy. Sourvy, Loprosy, and Lues Venerea
4 Greek, Latin Carcapuli Spanish. Italian. French. German. Dutch.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 393. Sarsaparilla of America. Smilax aspera Peruvana.

LIST.ITEM: 1. This Plant has slender prickly Stalks, the Leaves are a deep Green above and light underneath the Flowers white with green Stamina and white Apices, and the Roots a very dark Brown; This Specimen I had from the Malabar Garden Vol. 7. Tab. 31. and the Root from Mr. Nicholls.
2. It grows in Peru & Brasil, & flowers in August and September.

3. The Roots are heating, drying, attenuating & sudorific, & of great service in the Lues Venerea, for which it has been accounted a Specific and much used in Diec Drinks for that Purpose. It is accounted a great sweetner of the Blood, and is serviceable for the Gout, rheumatism, Scurvy, and King's Evil.
4. Greek, Latin, Smilax Peruvana Sarsaparilla. Spanish, Sarsa-parrilla de Peru. Italian, Zarsa-parille di Peru. French, Sarcepareille de Perou. German, Sarsa Parill. Dutch, Zalza Paril.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 394. Bitter & Sweet Costus. Costus amarus & dulcis.

LIST.ITEM: 1 The Stalks grow about four Foot high, the Leaves are a bright shining Green, the Flowers white with a yellow Apice. & red Calix The Costus dulcis is said to be the freshest Roots of this Tree, & the Costus amarus to be the oldest and stalest. This Specimen I had from ye Malabar Garden Vol 11. Tab 15. & I Root from Mr. Nicholls.
2 It grows in Malabar in the East Indies, and flowers in May.

3. Costus is esteem'd hot and dry, good to comfort the Head & Stomach, and help Vertiginous Disorders. It is also a good Deobstruent opening Obstructions of theWomb, and procuring the Catamenia. It is an Ingredient in the Theriaca; and the Electuarium Caryocostinum.
4. Greek. Latin, Costus Indicus odoratus Spanish, Costo amarago y dulce. Italian, Costo amaro & dolce. French, Costus Arabique. German, Frauwen Craut. Dutch, Kost Balsem.

2. It grows in the East Indies, and flowers in July & August.

3 Commelein has given a great many Virtues to the different Parts of this Tree see the Hortus Mal. as above; but our College of Physictitant have thought ye Nuts narcotic & poisonous & are generally used to kill Cats & Dogs.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 398. The Sebesten Plumb. Sebesten & Myxa

LIST.ITEM: 1. This Tree grows about the Bigness of our Plumb Trees, the Leaves are a deep shining Green above. & a dull hoary Green underweath. and the Flowers white encluded in a Green Ca, with white Stamina & yellow Apices with a light Green umbel in the Middle. I had this Specimen from the Malabar Garden Vol. 4. Tab 37. and the separate Fruit I had from Mr Joseph Clutton. Apothecary.
2 It grows in Malabar in the East Indies. and is always Green. bearing Fruit in July and August.
3. The Fruit is accounted cooling & moistning. good for sharp than Defluxions upon the Lungs. Coughs, Catarrhs, and heat of Urine.

2. It grows in Malabar in the East Indies and flowers on June

3. The Roots are esteem'd heating & drying. good to warm the Stomach, expell Wind. comfort the Bowels. stop Vomiting. and ease the Collie. They are also alexipharmic. and good in all Pestilential Distempers.
4. Greek. Latin, Zedoaria longa & rotunda. Spanish. Zedoar. Italian. Zedoarie French. Zedoaire. German. Ziwer. Dutch. Zedoar.

1. The Stalks grow about a Foot high, the Leaves are a deep Green above and light underneath; and the Flowers reddish.
2. It grows on Banks and Meadows, flowring in June.

3. Burnet is esteemed heating, drying, cordial and alexipharmic; and is often put into Wine, in the Summer, to give it a fine Flavor. The Powder of the Herb, or Root, is used for spitting of Blood, Bleeding at the Nose, or any other Flux or Haemorrhage. A Decoction of the Plant is accounted good for the Stone and Gravel. The Herb applyed outwardly is good to stay the Bleeding of Wounds and promote their Cure.
4. Greek, . Latin, Sanguisorba, & Pimpinella sanguisorba minor. Spanish, Italian, Pimpinella. French, Pimpinelle. German, Bibernell. Dutch, Pimpernelle.
1. The Stalks grow about two Foot high, the Leaves are a light grass Green, and the Flowers whitish.
2. It grows wild about Florence in Italy, but is nursed here in Gardens flowring in May.

3. The Roots only are used, being attenuating emollient & pectoral, good for Disorders of the Lungs, caused by sharp Humors falling on the tender Vesiculae. They help Coughs, Hoarsness & soreness at the Stomach; and are commended against the Gripes in Children; and to bring down the Obstructed Menses. Outwardly it is used in Perfumes, Sweet Bags & Hair Powder. It is an Ingredient in the Theriaca Andromachi, & Mithridate.
4. Greek, Latin, Illyrica. Iris alba Florentina. Spanish, Liria blanca de la Florencia. Italian, Giglio celeste. French, Glayeul blanche de la Florence. German, Gilgen. Dutch, Lich.

2. It is planted here in Gardens, and flowers in May.

3 The Root is heating drying and aperitive, & is frequently used in Sauces to create an Appetite. It is often used in Dyet Drinks, for the Scurvy. Prop and Jaundice, & is the Chief Ingredient in the Aqua Raphani composita.

2 It in moist Meadows, and is in the Pe in May.

1. This Bush has many trailing Branches; the Leaves are a grass Green. & the Flowers Red with yellow Apices.
2. It grows in the Southern Parts of France, and Italy; flowring in May.

3. The Capers that we use in Pickle are the Buds of the Flower; which are laid in the Sun to dry for a Day, and afterwards are put into Vinegar for eight Days, at which time they are shifted: this they repeat, and then they are barreld up for Use. Capers are accounted good to create an Appetite, provoke Urine, and help the Spleen and Jaundice. The Bark of the Root is heating and drying; opens Obstruc∣tions of the Liver & Spleen, helps the Rickets and hypocondriac Disorders.

3. This Plant is esteemd cephalic, stomatic and uterine, good for the Palsy, Epilepsy, and Green Sickness, promoting the Catamenia. Some commend it for Catarrhous Defluxions, old Coughs and spitting of Blood. The Distill'd Oil is good for the Tooth Ach.

3. Savory is heating drying and carminative, good to expel Wind from the Stomach and Bowels, help an Asthma and other Affections of the Breast. It is also good to open Obstructions of the Womb, & promote the Menses.

1. The Stalk grows about three or four Foot high; the Leaves are a bluish Green, and the flowers a pale greenish Purple.
2. It is sown in Gardens and flowers in June and July.

3. Leeks are more used in the Kitchen than in the Shops. They are esteemed warming and attenuating, good to cleanse the Lungs from tough Phlegm, help shortness of Breath and stoppage of the Stomach. The Juice is used to dissolve the Gums in the Pilulae foetidae.
4. Greek, . Latin, Porrum commune capitatum. Spanish, Puerro. Italian, Porro. French, Porreau. German, Lauch. Dutch, Parei.
1. The Stalks grow about four Foot high, the Leaves are yellowish when, ripe, and the Flower is Green.
2. It is sown in the Fields in March or April, and is ripe in July and August.

3. Oats are restringent and drying; and Oatmeal is of great Service both in Health and Sickness, being an wholsome and cleansing Food. Water Gruel made thereof is much used in all Kinds of Distempers. Oats fried and put into a Bag, and applyed to the Side, are good to ease pleuretic Pains; and applyed to the Belly they help the Collic and Pains in the Bowels.
4. Greek, . Latin, Avena vulgaris seu alba. Spanish, Avena. Italian, Vena & Gena. French, Avoine. German, Habern. Dutch, Haver

2. It is sown in the Spring and is ripe in July.

3. Barley is made into Bread in some Countries, & is much used by ye Brewer and the Distiller. It is accounted cooling mollifying & cleansing; a Decoction of it is of great Service in all kinds of Fevers & inflammatory Distempers, the Stone, Gravel, Heat and sharpness of Urine. Barley Broth is esteemed the best Nourishment in Acute Diseases. The Ptisana so much commended by antient Physicians, was made of husk'd Barley, boiled so long in Water till the Barley crackd, and the Liquor became thick like Cream.
4 Greek, Latin, Hordeum distichum. Spanish, Cevada. Italian, Orzo. French, Orge German, Geten Dutch, Get.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 425. The Black Cherry. Cerasus nigra.

LIST.ITEM: 1. This grows to be a pretty tall Tree; the Leaves are a deep grass Green, and the Blossoms white.
2. This Tree grows wild in several Parts of England, and flowers in April.

3. The Fruit is accounted cordial and cephalic and useful in all Diseases of the Head and Nerves, as Epilepsy, Convulsions & Palseys. Some commend it for the Stone, Gravel & stoppage of Urine. The Officinal Preparation is, the Distill'd Water; which is more used now than any other Simple Water.
4. Greek, . Latin, Cerasus major ac sylvestris fructu subdulci nigro colore inficiente. Spanish, Guindo. Italian, Grege. French, Cerisier. German, Fin Gersch-Baum. Dutch, Kerse-boom.
1. The Stalks grow about four or five Foot high, the Leaves are a light grass Green, and the Flowers white.
2. It is a Native of the Alps, and flowers in June.

3. The Herb and Seed are used, being esteem'd heating and drying, good to provoke Urine and the Menses, expell the Birh & After Birth and help Disorders of the Head and Womb. The Seeds are put into the Theriaca and Mithridate.
4. Greek, . Latin, Siler Montanum. Spanish, Sesamo. Italian, Seseli. French, Sesame. German, Steinbrech. Dutch, Esels Commyn.
1 The Stalks grows about eight Inches high, the Leaves are a deep Green and the Flowers white, with a yellow Spot in the Middle and several black Stripes running lengthways.
2 It grows in Fields and Commons flowring in July.

3. This Plant is famous for all Disorders of the Eyes, especially for Dimness of Sight, and to strengthen it when weak or decayed, either given in the Ju or Decochon, or the Powder of the Leaves. A Powder made of two Ounces of Eyebright, and half an Ounce of Mace is very much commended for the above Ends; especially after proper Evacuations. Some esteem it good for the Jaundice. The Officinal Preparation is the Aqua Euphrasiae
4 Greek, Latin, Euphrasia, & Euphrasia offiinarum Spanish, Eurasia. Italian, Euragia French, Eufraise. German, Augencrost. Dutch, Ooyen-croost

2. It is sown in Fields, and flowers in May.

3. Tares are seldome used now in the Shops, althô the Vulgar boil them in Milk, and give the Decoction to drive out the small Pox and Measles. Matthiotus says they are good to provoke Urine & help a Consumption, if they are boiled, and eat, in Barley Broth.

2. It grows in Mossy Ground at the Roots of Trees.

3. This Toothwort is accounted by Matthiolus, binding, cooling and cleansing. and good to promote Sleep. The Water distill'd from the Roots, he extolls as good for all sorts of Fluxes and the Epilepsy. Gerard says ye Country People used this Plant or Coughs, and all Disorders of the Lungs.

The Leaves are chiefly used, epecially against Distempers incident to the Female Sex, being of great service in promoting the menstrual Evacuations, either taken inwardly, or used outwardly in Baths & Semicupia. Some Recom∣mend this Plant as good to strengthen the Head & Nerves, & help hysteric Fits or Vapours. DIV2.HEAD: Plate 433. West India China. China occidentalis.

LIST.ITEM: 1 This Plant whose Root is the China, is a Species of prickly Bindweed; the Stalks grow about fifteen Foot high, when they have Trees to climb up. The Leaves are a deep grass Green and the Flowers a greenish Yellow.
2 It grows in Jamaica and other Parts of the West Indies.

3 China Roots are esteem'd sudorific and hepatic, good for the Gout, Dropsy, King's Evil and the Lues Venerea. Some Physicians prefer this to the Oriental China, especially in Scrophulous Cases and Consumptions, where there are any Suspicion that they arise from a Scrophulous Cause.

4 Greek, . Latin. Smilax aspera, fructu nigro, radice nodosa magna, laevi, farinacea, China dicta. Spanish, Volubiles aspero de las Indias occidentales. Italian. Smilace aspro di Indie occidentale. French. Volubilis aspre de Indi occidentale. German, Scharpffe Binden. Dutch, China-Wortel.
1. The Stalks grow about six or eight Foot high, the Leaves are a yellow∣ish Green and the Flowers yellow.
2. It is a Native of Syria, and flowers in June.

3. The Gum opponax is said to come from the wounded Root of this Plant; and is accounted heating & dissolving, good to evacuate tough Phlegm from the remote Parts of the Body, & on that account is useful against old Coughs and Asthmas; it helps the Gout. Sciatica, & Rheumatic Pains in the Limbs, and procures the Catamenta. Outwardly applyed it is good to dissolve hard Swellings, Tumors, pestilential Buboes, & Cure the Biting of Venemous Creatures.

2 It grows on Banks and dry Barren Places, flowring in June & July.

3. Yellow Bedstraw is accounted drying and inssating, good to stop all kinds of Fluxes & Haemorrhagies. and cure green Wounds. Some commend a Decoction of it for the Gout. and a Bath of it is very refreshing to wash the Feet after overwalking.
4. Greek, . Latin. Gallium luteum. Spanish, Coaja. leche Yerva Italian. Galio French, Pet Muguet. German. Meger Kraut. Dutch. Dal-stroo

3 The Seed is esteem'd a great diuretic. & a Cleanser of the Reins and Ureters. and good against the Stone. Gravel Stoppage & Heat of Urine. as also a Goorrhea. It is generally boild in ine or Water Matthiolus commends two Drums of the Powder to be given in omens. Milk as a speedy help in hand Labour

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 437. The smaller Tobacco. Nicotiana minor.

LIST.ITEM: 1. The Stalks grow about three Foot high, the Leaves are a deep grass Green, and the Flowers a pal Yellow.
2. It is sown in Gardens, flowring in June and July.

3. This Tobacco is not so much used as the other See Plate 146. being esteem'd to have less Vertue; but has much the same Qualities as the former, only in a less Degree. The Herb Women frequently impose the Leaves of this Plant, for those of the Mandragora; See Plate 364. on their unwary Customers. amarillo.
4. Greek, . Latin, Hyoscyamus luteus. Spanish. Velenho. Italian, Jusquiamo maggiore. French, Jusquiame. German, Bundteraut. Dutch, Dolkrud.
1 The Stalks on which the Flowers grow are about a Foot high, the Leaves are a light wellow Green, and the Flowers a bright Yellow.
2. It grows in the Southern Parts of France & Italy. and is planted here in Gardens, flowring in July and August.

3 This Stoecas is accounted good for Obstructions of the Liver and Spleen, it helps to dissolve congealed Blood and to provoke Urine. Matthiolus gives it great Commendations; but it is but seldom used in our Shops.
4. Greek, . Latin, Elichrysum, sen Stoechas citrina augustifolia. Spanish, Cantuesso. Italian, Amaranto giallo. French, Amaranth jaune. German, Reinblumen. Dutch, Staechas citrina.
1. The Stalks grow about two Foot high, the Leaves are a deep grass Green. and the Flowers yellow.
2. It grows wild in some Parts of England. & flowers in June and July.

3 Dioscorides says. That in his time, it was accounted good for the Jaundice, and to restore the Skin to its Colour. if the Decoction of it was taken. after coming out of a Bath. The Ox-Eye that is commonly used in the Shops is the Bellis major. See Plate 4.

Coloquintida is one of the strongest purging Simples, used in the Shops; it carrys off serous Humors & tough Phlegm from all Parts of the Body, with pretty much Violence, and is generally attended with griping. Nausea and some times Vomiting. But when given with proper Correctives, it is serviceable in all Pains of the Head & Nerves, helps the Rheumatism. Gout & Dropsy; and promotes the Menses. The Officinal Preparation is, The Trochisci Alhandal.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 442. The German Amomum. Amomum vulgare.

LIST.ITEM: 1. the Stalks grow about two Foot high, the Leaves are a bright grass Green, and the Flowers white.
2. It grows in Ditches and Banks, flowring in June & July.

3. The Seed is one of the four lesser Hot Seeds used in the Shops; and is accounted drying & attenuating, good to open Obstructions, cleanse ye Reins of Gravel, & promote the Menstrua. It is also esteem'd alexipharmic, for which it is put into ye Theriaca Andromachi, for a Succedaneum to the true Amomum.
4. Greek, . Latin, Sison, quod Amomum Officinis nostrum. Spanish. Apio. Italian, Petroselino Macedonico. French, Persil de Macedoine. German, Welscher Petersilien▪ Dutch, Piterselie van Macedonien.

2. It grows in Marshy Places, flowring in June & July.

3 The Root is one of the five opening Roots, used in the Shops; and is account∣ed duretic. and good for the stoppage of Urine, the Stone, the Gravel, Obstructions of the Liver & Spleen, the Dropsy, the Jaundice, & Obstructions of the Menses. The Leaves have much the same Qualities, and are eaten in the Spring to sweeten and purify the Blood. & help the Scurvy. The Seed is one of the four lesser hot Seeds used in the Shops; & is esteem'd earminative.

3. The Roots are esteem'd drying, binding and aleipharmic, & good for Diarrhaeas and Dissenteries, especially attended with malignant Fevers. They are also servicelable in Haemorrhagies of the Nose, Mouth or Womb; fasten loose Teeth, and help the fulling of the Uvula.

2. It grows in Waste Places and amongst Rubbish, and is cultivated also in Gardens, flowring in June.

3. The Seed of this Plant is what makes the Common Sauce call'd Mustard, which is a wholesome Condiment, provoking an Apetite, strengthening the Stomach, and helping Digestion: it is also good for the Head, Apoplexy, Leth∣argy & Palsy, especially of the Tongue. The Seed bruised & infused in Wine or Ale is of great service for the Scurvy and Dropsy, provoking Urine and the Menses. Outwardly applyed it is drawing and ripening; & laid on paralitic Members it recalls the Natural Heat.
4. Greek, . Latin, Sinapi Rapi folio. Spanish, Xenabe ô Xenable. Italian, Senapa. French. Seneve. German, Senff. Dutch, Mostert.

3. The Seed is one of the four lesser hot Seeds, used in the Shops; and is accounted drying & warming, good to expell Wind from the Stomach & Guts, and prevent the Collick. It is also diuretic, and helps to provoke Urine and the Courses.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 462. Dittany of Creet. Dictamnus Creticus.

LIST.ITEM: 1. The Stalks grow about a Foot high, the Leaves are a pale Green covered with Wood, except those on the young Stalks next the Top. which have no Wood. & the Flowers are a light Purple.
2. It grows chiefly in the Island of Creet or Candy & flowers in June.

3. This Plant was had in great Esteem among the Ancients particularly Virgil for its reputed Virtue of expelling the Arrows from wounded Bodies. It is still account∣ed alexipharmic. resisting Poison and all contagious pestilential Diseases; and is esteem'd good for the Bites or Stings of Venemous Creatures. It is of great Use to accelerate the Birth, expelling the Secundines and procuring the Catamenia. There is a good Quantity of it put into the Venice-Treacle, Mithridate and Diascordium. The Leaves are the only Part used.
4. Greek, . Latin, Dictamnus Creticus. Spanish, Dictamo. Italian, Dittamo di Candia. French, Dictame. German, Bilder-Poley. Dutch, Dictamnus van Candie.
1 This Bush grows about a Foot high, the Leaves are a bright grass Green and the Flowers a red Purple.
2. It grows on Heaths and in thin woody Places, in a boggy Soil, and generally among Ferns flowring in May.

3 The Fruit is cooling binding and grateful to the Stomach and good for Fluxes and Haemorrhagies. Symon Paul says they are much used against the Scurvy in Norway and other Northern Countries. An agreeable Syrup may be made of ye Juice, and used for all the above Intentions.
4. Greek, . Latin Myrllus & Vitis Idaea folies oblongis crenatis, fructis igricante. Spanish, Mirtho agreste Italian, Mirtillo. French, Airelle. Mirtlle German, Heidelleer. Dutch, Myrtill.

1. The Stalks grow about two Foot high that bear the Flowers, the Leaves are a yellow Green, and the Flowers a whitish Purple.
2. It grows in marshy boggy Grounds and flowers in May.

3. This Plant is esteemed a great antiscorbutic and very serviceable for the Gout, Rheumatism and Dropsy, for which Distempers it is much used in Diet Drinks. It is also a good stomatick, and is taken often in Intermitting Fevers.
4 Greek . Latin, Trifolium paludosum, et Menyanths. Spanish, Trebol elga Lagunsa. Italian, Trifoglio paludoso. French, Trifolio ou Trefel des mairais. German, Spicktlee. Dutch, Seven Betydenkruyd.
1 The Stalks grow about a Foot high, the Leaves are a deep grass Green. and the Flowers a light Purple.
2 It grows on marshy Places, especially in the Isle of Ely and flowers on July.

3 The Leaves are accounted sudorific & alexipharmic and a good Preservative & Remedy against all malignant and pestilential Diseases & putrid Fevery. They also Putre¦faction, destroy Worms & are good against the Bites of all Venemous Creatures. They are used on Venice Treacle & Mithridate and Diascordium kes Name from this Plant.
4. Greek, . Latin. Scordium. Spanish, Scordio. Italian, Scordi. French, Scar∣dium ou Chammaraz. German, Wasser-bnig. Dutch, Water-look

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 476. Carduus, or the Blessed Thistle Carduus benedictus.

LIST.ITEM: 1 The Stalks grow about three Foot high the Leaves are a light grass Green. and the Flowers yellow
2 It is sown every Year in Gardens flowring on June

3 This Plant takes its Name from the wholsome Qualities said to be in it. being accounted cordial & and sudorific and good for all sorts of malignant and pestilential Fevers, and for Agues of all kinds. It destroys Worms on the Stomach and is good against all sorts of Poison. The of it in Water or Pos-Drink is much used as a It is an Ingredient in the Water The offi and Preparation is the Aqua Cardu
4 Greek Latin benedictus Spanish bendito Italian French hardn end German bened Dutch

Carduus benedictus
1. This grows to be a tall Tree in the Native Soil; the Leaves are a bright grass Green, and the Catkins red.
2. It grows in the Stirian Alps, and the Mountains of Tirol and Carinthia; and sends forth its Catkins in March and April.

3 From the Trunk of this Tree the Venice Turpentine came which was formerly much used in the Shops, being of a browner Colour, and thicker than ye Strasburg, and of a more resinous Smell; but what goes under that Name now, is generally brought from New-england. Turpentine is heating, mollifying, and cleansing, good to stop a Gonorrhasa and the Fluor Albus. It Likewise provokes Urine, cleanses the Lungs, and is of great service outwardly in Ointments and Plaisters. Officinal Preparations are the Oleum and Balsamum Terebinthi.
4. Greek, . Latin, Larix. Spanish, Tea. Italian, Larice. French, Meleze. German, Lerchenbaum Dutch, Lorkenboom.
1 This grows to be a large Tree in the Eastern Countries, the Leaves are a bright grass Green, and the Flowers purple.
2. It grows in the Island of Chio, from whence we have the est Turpentine, and flowers in April.

3 The Liquid Rosin of this Tree was prefer'd by the Ancients to all other Kinds, now call'd Turpentines, for Affections of the Breast & Lungs, and for Diseases of ye Kidneys or Bladder, as Stone, Gravel and stoppage of Urine. It is frequently used for the Fluor Albus and Gonorrhaea.
4. Greek, Latin, Terebinthus vulgaris. Spanish, Cornicabra. Italian, Terebinto. French, Terebinte. German, Terpenteinbaum. Dutch, Terpent.
1 The Stalks grow about a Foot high, the Leaves are a light Green, and the Flowers white.
2 It grows by Road-sides and in Lanes, and flowers in June.

3 The Leaves and Tops are accounted hot, dry, and pectoral, and good to free the Lungs from tough Phlegm, especially in cold moist Constitutions the Juice being made into a Syrup with Sugar or Honey. They also open Obstructions of the Liver & Spleen and are very serviceable against the Dropsy. Jaundice Green Sickness structions of the Catamenia, suppression of the Lochia, & other Distempers of the female Sex for which few Herbs go beyond it. The Officinal Preparation is the Syrupus de Prass.
4 Greek, Latin, Prassium Spanish, Marrubio. Italian, Marrobio. French, Marrubuim Marrube blan German, , Andorn Dutch, Andorn, Malrow
1 The Stalks grow about two Foot high, the Leaves are a deep grass Green and the Flowers a reddish Purple.
2 It grows in Hedges & shady Banks and Months in the Summer
3 This is much of the Nature of being drying & binding & useful in Wounds & Pruees as well as in for ye and all rephuleus Swellings and has done Service in Nephrtic Cases

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 481. Sea Lavender. Limonium & Behen rubrum.

LIST.ITEM: 1. The Stalks grow about a Foot high, the Leaves are a grass Green, and the Flower Purple.
2. It grows commonly in Salt Marshes, as below Greenhith, and Gravesend in ve∣ry great Plenty and flowers in July and August.
3. The Roots and Seed are esteem'd restringent & binding; and good for a Diarrhea, Dysentary, the too great Abundance of the Menses and the Fluor Albus.
4. Greek, . Latin, Limonium maritimum majus. Spanish, Espliego de Mar. Italian, Lavanda di Mare. French, Lavande de Mer. German, Dutch, Limoen-kruyd.
1 The Stalk grows about three Foot high, the Leaves are a willow Green, and the Flowers a pale Purple with a black Bottom.
2 It is sown yearly in Gardens, and flowers in July.

3 The Heads were formerly used in the Sirupus Meconio, but are left out in the last Edition of the Dispensatory. The Leaves are used in Cooling Oint∣ments, being accounted good for Burns, Inflammations, and hot Swellings, and are put in the Unguentum Populeon.
4. Greek, . Latin, Papaver hortense nigro semine. Spanish, Dormidera negra. Italian, Papavero nero. French, Povot noir. German, Schwarter Magsamen. Dutch, Swarte Houl.
1. The Stalks grow about six Foot high, the Leaves are a pale Green, and the Flowers white.
2. It is sown in Field and Gardens, and flowers in June.

3 From the Heads of these Poppies (in Turky) the opium of our Shops is produced by making Incisions into them, the milky Juice which comes from the Wounds, is soon thickned by the Heat of the Sun, and then gathered and made up into Lumps Opium is the greatest Anodine we have easing Pain, procuring Sleep, stopping all violent Evacuations, and is an excellent Medicine in the Hands of a Wise Man, and ought never to be prescribed by any other, many fatal Accidents ensuing from the immoderate or unseasonable Use of it. The Syrupus e Meconto or Da∣codium is made of the Poppy Heads dryed, infused & boiled in Water. The Seeds are much used in Emulsions being cooling and good in Fevers, inflammatory Distempers, the Strangury and Heat of Urine.
4. Greek, . Latin, Papaver hortense semine albo. Spanish, Dormi¦dera blanca Italian, Papavero banco. French, Pavot blanc. German, Weiss Magsamen Dutch, Witte Heul.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 484 The Lesser Valerian. Valeriana minor.

LIST.ITEM: 1 The Stalks grow about a Foot high, the Leaves are a grass Green, and the Flowers a pale Purple
2 It grows in Marshy Grounds Meadows and flowers in May.

3 Mattholus gives mitch the same Virtues to this Valerian as he does to the other Valerian, only in a less Degree (see Plate 250 & Plate 271) but this Species is rarely used in the Shoo now the other being esteemed much better.

1. Monardus says that this grows to be a large Tree in its Native Climate, the Leaves are a grass Green, and the Bark of the Trunk ash Colour; in which they make Incisions, and the Resinous Gum, that flows from the Wounds, is the Liquid Amber of the Shops.
2. It grows in several Parts of the West Indies.
3. It is esteemed of a heating resolving Nature, good to open Obstructions. and help the Hardness of the Womb.
4. Greek, Latin, Liquidambra. Spanish. Liquidambar. Italian. Liquid∣ambra. French. Liquidambar. German. Dutch.
1. This seldom grows to be a call Tree; the Leaves are a bluish dark Green on the Face, and a light willow Green on the Back, & the Flowers a whitish yellow.
2. It grows in Italy. Spain and Turky, and flowers in May and June.

3. The Leaves and Seed are accounted restringent and Stiptic. and good for all Fluxes and Haemorrhagies; both used inwardly and outwardly. They are also good to resest Putrefactions and stop Gangreens and Mortifycations. They are used in the Syrupus Myrtinus.
4. Greek, . Latin. Samach. Spanish. Sumagre. Italian, Somacho. French, Sumac. German, Gerberbaum. Dutch, Smack.
1. This grows to be a very tall Tree, the Leaves are a bright grass Green. and the Fruit a brownish Green when ripe.
2. It grows in great plenty in this Country, and its Acorns are ripe in September.

3. The Bark, Buds, Acorns, Cups, and Galls are used: and are accounted Stiptic and binding and useful in all kinds of Fluxes and Bleedings, either Inward or Outward The Bark is often used for the Relaxation of the Uvula, & for sore Mouths and Throats. and is put in restringent Glysters & Infections against the Prolapsus Uteri or Ani. The Vulgar requently beat the Acorns is Powder, and take it for Pains in the Side The Officinal Preparation is the Aqua Germinum Quercus.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 489. Patience. Lapathum sativum et Patientia.

LIST.ITEM: 1 The Stalks grow about six Foot high, the Leaves are a grass Green. and the Flowers yellow.
2. It is planted here in Gardens, and flowers in July.

3. The Root is opening and purging, being somewhat of the Nature of the true Rhubarb, but not so strong; and is often used in Diet-Drinks for the Scurvy, and to open Obstructions of the Liver & Spleen, and help the Jaundice.
4. Greek, . Latin, Lapathum hortense. Spanish. Acedera cevada. Italian, Rombice maggiore. French. Patience German Munch Rhabarbaren. Dutch. Patientie.

DIV2.HEAD: Plate 490. The great Water Dock. Lapathum aquaticum.

LIST.ITEM: 1 The Stalks grow about five Foot high, the Leaves are a grass Green. and the Flowers yellow.
2. It grows in Ponds and Ditches, flowring in July.

3 There is a particular Treatise wrote on this Plant, by Muntingius, who sup poses it to be the Britanica of the Ancients, and attributes to it all the Virtues that they ascribe to their Britanica; as being of great Service against the Scurvy & all its Symtoms, as Ulcers in the Mouth and Gums. Loosness of Teeth, Pains in the Limbs, as likewise against all kinds of Fluxes, the Dropsy and Jaundice.
4. Greek. . Latin. Hydrolapathum. Spanish. Acadera agatila. Italian, Lapatio aquatico. French. Lapais aquatique. German. Mengernurt Dutch. Water Patich.
1 The Stalks grow about three Foot high. the Leaves are a grass Green, and the Flowers a greenish yellow.
2 It grows common in moist Places, and flowers in June.

3 The Roots are accounted aperative & cooling, and much used to purisy and cleanse the Blood from salt sharp Humours: and are good for the Scurvy Rheumatism, and all manner of itchy seabby Eruptions, for which Purpose they are frequently put in Diet-Drinks & apozems, and used outwardly in Ointments. The Seed is drying and binding, good to stop spitting of Blood, and Haemorrhagies of all Kinds.
4 Greek. . Latin, Oxylapathum. Spanish. Labara. Italian. Lapatio French. Lapais. ou Pareile German, Streiffwart. Dutch, Wilde Patich.
1 The Stalks grow about three Foot high. the Leaves are a grass Green. veined with Red. and the Flowers a pale Green.
2 It is planted in Gardens. and flowers in June.
3 Matthiolus. says thes has the same Qualities as the Sharp-pointed Dock only he prese it to the sormer in all sorts of Fluxes & Haemorrhages

The Leaves are good to be applyed to hot Tumors and Inslammations.
